3.32.text:
Welcome to this training session. We will
be looking at how candidates performed in

8.60.text:
paper 2 of the Edexcel iGCSE and Edexcel Certificate
for Chinese. You will trial mark some samples

17.92.text:
of candidate work, so that you may understand
how the examining team applied the marking

23.23.text:
criteria. There will also be some ideas on
how to teach and prepare future candidates

29.20.text:
for this examination.
You may find it useful to have to hand the

41.24.text:
specification, a copy of the 2015 examination
paper, together with its Mark Scheme and the

48.17.text:
examiner's report.
During this training event you will hear feedback

56.60.text:
on how candidates performed, receive some
teaching ideas, practice using the marking

62.15.text:
criteria for the writing questions, and be
given some ideas on how you may be able to

68.18.text:
help candidates to improve their writing.
Let's start by looking at the structure of

78.09.text:
the paper. You may find it helpful to have
a copy of the 2015 question paper open in

83.59.text:
front of you at this point. The paper is offered
in both traditional and simplified character

90.20.text:
versions, and the candidate should choose
one. Questions 1, 2, 3 part (a) and 4 are

97.15.text:
reading questions. These questions require
candidates to tick boxes, or answer using

103.48.text:
A, B, C and so do not require candidates to
write any Chinese characters. Question 3 (b)

111.97.text:
is a short writing question. There is quite
a lot of support for candidates in this question:

118.63.text:
firstly the guiding questions are given both
in English and Chinese, and secondly, the

124.80.text:
theme of question 3 (b) is related to question
3 (a), so candidates can refer back to question

131.88.text:
3 (a) for vocabulary support.
Question 5 is a longer passage for reading,

138.32.text:
with comprehension questions in Chinese. Candidates
must answer these questions in Chinese: no

144.59.text:
credit is given for answers in either pinyin
or English.

148.43.text:
Question 6 is a longer writing question. The
candidates have a choice of three questions

155.44.text:
from which they choose one.
We will look at each of these questions in

164.84.text:
turn.
Most candidates who take this examination

169.25.text:
find the reading questions reasonably easy,
and many candidates gain full marks. If you

175.60.text:
look at the examiner's report, you will see
that questions 1, 2, 3 (a) and 4 caused no

183.23.text:
significant difficulty for most candidates.
There are of course many different ways to

194.68.text:
teach candidates how to recognize and read
Chinese characters. Obviously the traditional

200.73.text:
use of physical worksheets and flash cards
still works well. But if your candidates are

207.01.text:
interested in using their mobile phones of
tablets to learn characters, you may be interested

212.59.text:
in taking a look at some of these websites,
the addresses of which you can see on the

217.67.text:
screen. These can be used as websites or as
apps. Do search first to see what other teachers

225.21.text:
have loaded before you spend a lot of time
loading your own materials, as often for these

230.44.text:
examination syllabuses someone has already
loaded all the vocabulary candidates need.

236.47.text:
There are of course other websites and apps
available.

246.90.text:
Here is question 3 (b), the writing question,
from the summer 2015 regional paper. You will

254.84.text:
see that the question is given both in Chinese
and in English to offer candidates maximum

261.26.text:
support. If they wish, candidates can read
the questions in English to understand what

267.60.text:
they are being asked to do, and then use the
questions in Chinese to support their writing,

273.59.text:
for example by copying characters or sentence
structures. They can also use some of the

280.44.text:
vocabulary from question 3 (a) if they wish.
For example, in the reading passage for 3

286.85.text:
(a), the words for Shanghai, boat, chopsticks,
Chinese paintings were all used, so candidates

296.18.text:
could have copied these into their answers.
In the next few slides we are going to see

302.23.text:
some candidate responses and mark them, so
at this point please find the marking criteria.

309.84.text:
You can find these either on pages 5 and 6
of the examiner's report or on page 12 of

317.12.text:
the specification. Please notice that candidates
can score 3 or possibly even 4 marks for communication

326.01.text:
and content even if they have copied from
the supporting passage, providing they have

331.20.text:
made some attempt to adapt it.
Here is the first piece of candidate work.

342.39.text:
Please mark it, referring to the marking criteria.
You may like to pause the recording until

348.86.text:
you have finished marking.
This candidate was given full marks, in other

365.84.text:
words 5 marks, for communication and content,
and 4 marks for knowledge and application

372.44.text:
of language. What this candidate has done
well is to focus on the questions asked, and

379.37.text:
made sure that there were clear answers to
each of the questions, even if those answers

384.47.text:
were quite short and basic. The candidate
has also used 'for example' quite effectively

391.62.text:
to show off 3 foods she can write. Finally
the candidate has used a 'because' clause,

398.87.text:
which was given credit as part of a range
of structures. The writing is quite repetitive,

405.60.text:
so to improve this candidate's work further,
the candidate could be shown where the work

410.70.text:
is repetitive, and be taught some alternative
phrases to use. The candidate should also

417.05.text:
work on the accuracy of writing each individual
character.

422.41.text:
Here is a second piece of candidate work.
Please mark it, referring to the marking criteria.

434.05.text:
You may like to pause the recording until
you have finished marking.

444.14.text:
This candidate was given 1 for communication
and content. This is because they have only

456.78.text:
answered 1 of the questions out of the 5 asked
in the bullet points. The candidate was also

463.75.text:
given 1 for knowledge and application of language.
Whilst their formation of characters is good,

470.06.text:
the whole piece is far too short, and this
would fall under the descriptor 'Narrow range

476.40.text:
of vocabulary and structures'.
To help this candidate get a better mark next

481.47.text:
time, you could practice looking at the questions.
For example 'What did you eat', and helping

488.19.text:
them to use the question as a model to write
very simple answers such as 'I ate meat',

497.11.text:
'I ate fish', 'I ate fruit' and so on. This
would probably show that the candidate doesn't

501.93.text:
know enough characters to write basic vocabulary,
so you could also teach them 5 foods, 5 places

510.05.text:
to go, 5 activities, 5 colours and so on.
The candidate seems to know 'I like China'

517.63.text:
as a set phrase, and may also have benefitted
from learning a few more set sentences, for

523.65.text:
example 'I went with my friends'. 'Chinese
food is very tasty' and so on.

536.96.text:
Here is a third piece of candidate work. Please
mark it, referring to the marking criteria.

542.10.text:
Again, you may like to pause the recording
until you have finished marking.

550.71.text:
This candidate was given 2 for communication
and content, and 3 for knowledge and application

564.82.text:
of language.
Unfortunately although the candidate is trying

568.62.text:
to answer the bullet points and has tried
really hard to write difficult characters,

573.70.text:
because there are errors in the basic sentence
structure, it is sometimes difficult to understand

578.68.text:
what they are saying. This is why it would
have been put into the mark band 'only occasionally

584.74.text:
comprehensible'. This candidate would be better
off being taught to answer the question clearly

591.71.text:
and accurately, even if the language is very
basic. Please also try to persuade the candidate

598.36.text:
that copying out lots of difficult characters
doesn't lead to a high mark.

605.90.text:
Here is the last piece of candidate work for
question 3 (b). Please mark it, referring

613.02.text:
to the marking criteria. You may like to pause
the recording until you have finished marking.

623.44.text:
This piece was given 4 for both communication
and content and knowledge and application

639.37.text:
of language. One very obvious mistake this
candidate made was to miss out the answer

645.07.text:
to the why question on the bullet point about
shopping. This accounts for the lost mark

650.80.text:
in the communication and content criterion.
Often even very able candidates lose marks

657.76.text:
on this criterion because they miss out answering
one of the bullet points, so it is always

663.57.text:
worth reminding them to double check their
work to make sure they haven't missed anything

669.22.text:
out.
This candidate has clearly worked quite hard

672.88.text:
to memorize good chunks of language, for example,
'with my brothers and sisters' and 'afterwards'.

679.03.text:
Having a range of language like this memorized
and available to drop into any piece of writing

685.51.text:
is a very good language learning technique.
It's a shame that there are some small errors

691.55.text:
of word order and characters in this candidate's
memorized language, and since he has come

696.82.text:
so far already with learning characters, he
could be encouraged to take the last small

701.68.text:
step to get it 100% accurate.
We're now going to look at question 5. This

713.30.text:
is a longer reading passage, in which candidates
have to answer the questions in Chinese. Please

718.85.text:
emphasize to candidates that they must write
their answers in characters: any answers in

724.94.text:
pinyin or in English will not be given marks.
In preparing candidates for this question,

730.66.text:
do drill them on all the key question words.
If they recognize the question word 'who'

736.52.text:
in the question, at least they won't then
be looking for a food item as an answer, and

741.18.text:
so on. It will also help candidates to know
that the answers come in the order of the

748.97.text:
text, and that they don't need to answer in
full sentences. They also need to watch out

752.12.text:
for 2 mark questions. If the question has
2 marks, they must write 2 different answers,

758.85.text:
otherwise they will only score 1 mark.
Let's have a look at one candidate's response

770.09.text:
to illustrate the points made in the previous
slide. This is not the complete response by

775.00.text:
the candidate, but you can see that in both
parts (d) and (i), the candidate has not understood

781.17.text:
the key question word. This candidate is also
showing the typical tendency of slightly weaker

787.29.text:
candidates to match up characters in the questions
with characters in the passage, and then copy

791.86.text:
out that section from the passage in the hope
that the answer is found there. The candidate

797.39.text:
needs to understand the question being asked,
and find the relevant information to answer

801.73.text:
the question, rather than copying out sections
of text in the hope that the answer is somewhere

811.22.text:
We're now going to look at question 6, which
is the long writing question. Candidates are

820.06.text:
required to write between 100 and 150 characters,
from a choice of three questions. The questions

828.23.text:
are all written in Chinese with no English
support, so it's crucial that candidates spend

834.46.text:
sufficient time reading the questions to make
sure that they understand the bullet points,

838.85.text:
and choose a question that they fully understand.
The bullet points are generally arranged so

844.33.text:
that if candidates write a short paragraph
on each point, they should have a reasonably

849.27.text:
well structured piece of the correct length.
We're now going to look at some student samples

856.05.text:
again, so you will need to find the marking
criteria. You will be able to find this either

861.17.text:
on page 8 of the mark scheme, or on page 13
of the specification.

869.50.text:
This is question 6 c from this year's paper.
It was popular with candidates as it is on

880.47.text:
the familiar topic of food, and the last bullet
point gives them the opportunity to write

885.73.text:
about activities, both of which candidates
will have practiced in class and feel comfortable

891.06.text:
with. Notice how this question gives them
plenty of opportunity to use material they

896.84.text:
may have practiced in class. For example,
the question 'What do you like eating?' gives

902.64.text:
them the opportunity not only to show off
their food vocabulary, but also write a sentence

909.79.text:
including a because clause. Similarly, they
could use some pre-learnt material about describing

914.91.text:
their house in answering the bullet point
about where they eat their lunch, and so on.

920.69.text:
Candidates who are aiming to get top marks
should make sure that they respond fully to

924.99.text:
the last bullet point which asks for their
opinion.

930.34.text:
Here is the first piece of candidate work
to look at. Please use the marking criteria

940.10.text:
to mark it, noting that it goes across the
next three slides. You may wish to pause the

945.89.text:
recording until you have had a chance to look
at this piece of work and come up with your

960.71.text:
You will see that this candidate has been
awarded 5 marks for communication and content,

983.50.text:
2 marks for knowledge and application of language
and 3 marks for accuracy.

990.68.text:
In terms of communication and content, the
candidate has addressed each of the bullet

1000.24.text:
points, but the answers are generally quite
basic. It would have helped if the candidate

1006.15.text:
had written a separate paragraph for each
bullet point, which tends to focus candidates'

1010.99.text:
minds on what they should be writing, and
also acts as a check on whether they have

1016.58.text:
written enough.
Sometimes the language errors make the communication

1020.15.text:
unclear: this is partly because the candidate
is trying to write in quite long sentences,

1026.14.text:
and loses the grammatical thread between the
beginning and the end of the sentence.

1037.85.text:
Here is another candidate's work. Again, please
use the marking criteria to mark it for yourself.

1043.72.text:
You may wish to pause the recording until
you have done this.

1059.67.text:
You will immediately see that this candidate
has not written the minimum 100 characters

1064.53.text:
required for this task. This piece was given
2 for communication and content, 2 for knowledge

1071.11.text:
and application of language and 2 for accuracy.
The candidate has clearly tried to write a

1083.66.text:
sentence in response to each bullet point.
To improve their work further, they could

1087.80.text:
be encouraged to add another sentence giving
extra information each time they write a response

1093.26.text:
to a bullet point. They also need to practice
getting the correct character where there

1097.98.text:
are several characters which sound the same
but mean different things. Currently the candidate

1102.98.text:
is only using very basic sentence structures,
so they could improve their mark by beginning

1108.18.text:
to use some slightly longer and more ambitious
sentences, even if they are just using these

1113.21.text:
as set phrases to start with.
Here is the final piece of candidate work

1121.32.text:
we are going to look at today. Again, please
use the marking criteria to mark it for yourself,

1130.57.text:
noting that once again it spreads over 3 slides.
You may wish to pause the recording until

1150.83.text:
You will see that this candidate was awarded
8 for communication and content, which is

1168.90.text:
a very good mark, 3 for knowledge and application
of language and 3 for accuracy.

1182.11.text:
What this candidate has done really well is
to not only address each bullet point, but

1187.20.text:
to make sure that each one is expanded by
adding two or three extra sentences. The candidate

1193.78.text:
has used the words 'for example' very effectively
to show off a range of vocabulary, although

1200.86.text:
long lists of nouns by themselves are not
sufficient to score high marks. To get a better

1207.24.text:
mark, this candidate needs to work on using
the grammatical structures they have clearly

1211.27.text:
begun to learn with greater accuracy. They
should also being to learn a wider range of

1216.92.text:
phrases for giving opinions.
We are approaching the end of our training

1228.00.text:
session today, but please take a look at the
screen which will guide you to further sources

1232.82.text:
of information about this specification and
statistics for the 2015 examination. I am

1239.11.text:
sure you are aware that Edexcel's website,
www.edexcel.com, has a huge range of very

1246.90.text:
useful information to support your teaching
of this specification. Please remember too

1252.52.text:
that Edexcel offers an 'ask the expert' service,
which again you can find through the website.

1258.83.text:
This service is for any more specific, individual
questions you may have which are not answered

1264.70.text:
by the general guidance given on the website.
Thank you very much for participating in this

1275.34.text:
training today. We are constantly seeking
to improve the training we offer, so please

1281.49.text:
spare a couple of minutes to fill in the feedback
form which you will receive in an email link.
